title: Wales coach Warren Gatland says his side will not relent ahead of Fiji clash
text:
Wales will go into the quarter-finals with a mental edge if they leave their pool unbeaten, according to Warren Gatland.

After wins against Georgia and Australia Wales are flying with Fiji and Uruguay to come.

Wales have only gone unbeaten once in a World Cup Pool stage - back in 1987 when they ended third, their best ever finish.

Warren Gatland is hoping Wales can keep their momentum going ahead of the quarter-finals

And Gatland - in his last World Cup - is set to pick the big-guns again against Fiji in order to keep momentum going.

'If you win the group it's a big psychological boost because you're playing a quarter-final against a team who would have definitely lost a game in their pool,' he said.

'I think psychologically it's quite important for us to win this group, win the next two games, and then to start thinking about our quarter-final opponent.

'The next two matches are very important.

Gatland revealed that his squad would be 'chomping at the bit' to take on Uruguay after Fiji

'Fiji are going to be tough for us. They had a great performance against Georgia.

'They're very much a confidence side so we'll have to be on top of our game and be defensively strong at the set-piece.

'We've got a short turnaround of four games so a lot of the players who haven't had any rugby will get an opportunity then.

'They'll be chomping at the bit to play against Uruguay.'
description: Wales will go into the quarter-finals with a mental edge if they leave their pool unbeaten, according to Warren Gatland.
authors: Will Kelleher For The Mail On Sunday
